We compare our method with the state-of-the-art (SOTA) algorithms FedAvgÂ [25], FedProxÂ [23], SCAFFOLDÂ [16] and FedDynÂ [2]. The analysis is presented both in terms of convergence performance (FigureÂ 2, TableÂ I) and speed (TableÂ II). Taking into account both the convergence performance and rates, the best configuration chosen for FedSeq is based on the greedy grouping algorithm with KL-divergence applied on confidence vectors, i.e. GS={Ïˆconf,Ï•greedy,Ï„Kâ€‹L}subscriptğºğ‘†subscriptğœ“confsubscriptitalic-Ï•greedysubscriptğœğ¾ğ¿G_{S}=\{\psi_{\textnormal{conf}},\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}},\tau_{KL}\}.
In addition, all results are compared with FedSeqInter, which adds the inter-superclient sequential training to this configuration, and is shown to outperform any configuration of FedSeq.

Table I shows how FedSeqÂ reaches consistently better results than other methods not only when addressing extreme data heterogeneity, but also when faced with less severe conditions. This behavior reflects equally on both datasets. In particular, FedProx seems unable to address extreme scenarios, maintaining performances comparable to FedAvg. SCAFFOLD proves itself effective in addressing the most unbalance case (Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0), with +7%percent7+7\% at convergence on Cifar-10, but fails at improving the results achieved by FedAvg both in more moderate scenarios and on Cifar-100. We found FedDyn to be the best current state-of-the-art algorithm, reaching the target accuracies for all configurations except Cifar-100 with Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0. FedSeqÂ successfully address the challenge of extremely unbalanced clients on both datasets, outperforming FedAvg, FedProx and SCAFFOLD both in terms of final performance and convergence speed, being on par with FedDyn in the average case (Figure 2). FedSeqInter - although initially slower - reaches the highest accuracy value, close to that of the centralized scenario Aâ€‹câ€‹ccâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹rğ´ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘ŸAcc_{centr}: in the most challenging setting, the achieved value corresponds to 96.4%â‹…Aâ€‹câ€‹ccâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹râ‹…percent96.4ğ´ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ96.4\%\cdot Acc_{centr} on Cifar-10 and 91.2%â‹…Aâ€‹câ€‹ccâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹râ‹…percent91.2ğ´ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ91.2\%\cdot Acc_{centr} on Cifar-100.
That tells us that aggregating every NSsubscriptğ‘ğ‘†N_{S} rounds not only leads to less frequent synchronization between clients and server with a consequent speed up of the training process, but also improves the accuracy reached.

Since FedSeq keeps the same logic of FedAvg both in the local training and the server-side aggregation, it can be easily integrated with other approaches modifying those parts of the algorithm. In particular, we evaluate the performance of FedProxÂ [23] and FedDynÂ [2] on top of FedSeq, since changes to the local objective are straightforward to transfer in our sequential training framework.
FedProx adds a proximal term Î¼ğœ‡\mu to the local objective to improve stability and regularize the distance between the local and global models.
We can repurpose FedProx to be used in our sequential framework by adding a proximal term to retain the information learned by the previous client rather than the global model, with potential benefits in the most challenging settings.
Similarly FedDyn can be integrated in FedSeq by adding both linear and quadratic penalty terms to the loss function, using the model trained by the previous client in place of the serverâ€™s last model (see Appendix -F for the details).
Results in TableÂ I show that integrating FedSeq with FedProx makes the algorithm converge slightly faster only in the most unbalanced scenario, while performances are on par in the remaining the cases.

references: We evaluate FedSeqÂ on image classification tasks from Cifar-10 and Cifar-100, widely used as benchmarks in FL. In order to set up a heterogeneous scenario, the local class distribution is sampled from a Dirichlet distribution with Î±âˆˆ{0,0.2,0.5}ğ›¼00.20.5\alpha\in\{0,0.2,0.5\} [12]. Implementation details can be found in Appendix -E. We evaluate our results in terms of global accuracy on the test set (Tables I and III) and convergence rates (Table II). All reported results are averaged over the last 100 rounds.

We compare our method with the state-of-the-art (SOTA) algorithms FedAvgÂ [25], FedProxÂ [23], SCAFFOLDÂ [16] and FedDynÂ [2]. The analysis is presented both in terms of convergence performance (FigureÂ 2, TableÂ I) and speed (TableÂ II). Taking into account both the convergence performance and rates, the best configuration chosen for FedSeq is based on the greedy grouping algorithm with KL-divergence applied on confidence vectors, i.e. GS={Ïˆconf,Ï•greedy,Ï„Kâ€‹L}subscriptğºğ‘†subscriptğœ“confsubscriptitalic-Ï•greedysubscriptğœğ¾ğ¿G_{S}=\{\psi_{\textnormal{conf}},\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}},\tau_{KL}\}.
In addition, all results are compared with FedSeqInter, which adds the inter-superclient sequential training to this configuration, and is shown to outperform any configuration of FedSeq.

In TableÂ II, we report the time (indicated as number of rounds) needed by our best configurations and SOTAs to reach respectively the 70%percent7070\%, 80%percent8080\% and 90%percent9090\% of the centralized accuracy,
also indicating the speedup relative to FedAvg. Considering the most challenging situations, on Cifar-10, FedSeq based on the KL divergence on confidence vectors is 777 times faster than FedAvg and successfully reaches the 90%percent9090\% of the centralized accuracy in less than a third of rounds budget; on Cifar-100, FedSeqInter is the only algorithm able to reach the 90%percent9090\% of the centralized accuracy, in less than half of the available rounds. As highlighted by [36], we confirm that FedDyn is prone to parameters explosion in extremely imbalanced settings: when run on Cifar-100 with Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, the model fails to converge.

It is to be noted the percentage of classes covered is a less discriminatory measure, as the class is accounted for as present even if only one of its samples is in the superclient, while a low deviation from the mean of the samples per class is necessary to have a higher balance ratio, making the latter more reliable.
In Appendix -C, Table IV shows the results varying by Ïˆğœ“\psi, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and Ï„ğœ\tau. The first consideration is the random assignment strategy (Ï•randsubscriptitalic-Ï•rand\phi_{\textnormal{rand}}) has surprisingly good indices.The reason lies in statistical considerations on the setting: when Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, there are multiple clients (i.e. 50 clients in Cifar-10 and 5 in Cifar-100) having samples belonging to the same class; thus, a random choice in unlikely to group only those clients with the same data distribution. As Î±ğ›¼\alpha grows, each client has a more homogeneous distribution, so every clustering criterion leads to a similar result. Ï•kmeanssubscriptitalic-Ï•kmeans\phi_{\textnormal{kmeans}} has the best performances when Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, with zero variance on the number of clients in the same set, while Ï•greedysubscriptitalic-Ï•greedy\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}} is the best one on average,
becoming our algorithm of choice. Figures in Appendix -D show examples of superclients built with different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi.
As for the approximators, it is possible to see that, fixed the choice of Ï•greedysubscriptitalic-Ï•greedy\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}}, the use of Ïˆclfsubscriptğœ“clf\psi_{\textnormal{clf}} leads to higher balance ratio, especially when Ï„cosinesubscriptğœcosine\tau_{\textnormal{cosine}} is adopted, while Table III shows that Ïˆconfsubscriptğœ“conf\psi_{\textnormal{conf}} brings towards higher accuracy. As for the metrics, the speedup with Ï„KLsubscriptğœKL\tau_{\textnormal{KL}} is more prominent (Table II). So our approximator of choice is Ïˆconfsubscriptğœ“conf\psi_{\textnormal{conf}} with Ï„KLsubscriptğœKL\tau_{\textnormal{KL}}.

Starting from client kğ‘˜kâ€™s data approximation ğ’Ÿ~ksubscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘˜\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{k}, we build similar superclients from users having different distributions, i.e. we aim at minimizing the inter-superclients distance while maximizing the intra-superclient one.
To do so, given ğ’Ÿi~~subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\tilde{\mathcal{D}_{i}} and ğ’Ÿj~~subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—\tilde{\mathcal{D}_{j}}, we need a metric Ï„â€‹(ğ’Ÿi~,ğ’Ÿj~):â„NCÃ—NCâ†’â„:ğœ~subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–~subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—â†’superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘ğ¶subscriptğ‘ğ¶â„\tau(\tilde{\mathcal{D}_{i}},\tilde{\mathcal{D}_{j}}):\mathbb{R}^{N_{C}\times N_{C}}\to\mathbb{R} to measure the distance between the two distribution estimates. We choose the Euclidean distance and cosine similarity to compare the weights of the clientsâ€™ classifier,
although other popular metrics can be usedÂ [37].
Alternatively, more sophisticated techniques learning features representation and cluster assignment can be used, such as [33]. Since satisfying results were reached with the standard metrics (Table IV), we have decided to favor a simpler and sufficiently effective approach.
When ğ’Ÿk~~subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\tilde{\mathcal{D}_{k}} as the form of an actual probability distribution given by the confidence vector, we also adopt two disomogeneity measures, the Gini index [9] and the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence [19].

It is to be noted the percentage of classes covered is a less discriminatory measure, as the class is accounted for as present even if only one of its samples is in the superclient, while a low deviation from the mean of the samples per class is necessary to have a higher balance ratio, making the latter more reliable.
In Appendix -C, Table IV shows the results varying by Ïˆğœ“\psi, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and Ï„ğœ\tau. The first consideration is the random assignment strategy (Ï•randsubscriptitalic-Ï•rand\phi_{\textnormal{rand}}) has surprisingly good indices.The reason lies in statistical considerations on the setting: when Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, there are multiple clients (i.e. 50 clients in Cifar-10 and 5 in Cifar-100) having samples belonging to the same class; thus, a random choice in unlikely to group only those clients with the same data distribution. As Î±ğ›¼\alpha grows, each client has a more homogeneous distribution, so every clustering criterion leads to a similar result. Ï•kmeanssubscriptitalic-Ï•kmeans\phi_{\textnormal{kmeans}} has the best performances when Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, with zero variance on the number of clients in the same set, while Ï•greedysubscriptitalic-Ï•greedy\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}} is the best one on average,
becoming our algorithm of choice. Figures in Appendix -D show examples of superclients built with different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi.
As for the approximators, it is possible to see that, fixed the choice of Ï•greedysubscriptitalic-Ï•greedy\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}}, the use of Ïˆclfsubscriptğœ“clf\psi_{\textnormal{clf}} leads to higher balance ratio, especially when Ï„cosinesubscriptğœcosine\tau_{\textnormal{cosine}} is adopted, while Table III shows that Ïˆconfsubscriptğœ“conf\psi_{\textnormal{conf}} brings towards higher accuracy. As for the metrics, the speedup with Ï„KLsubscriptğœKL\tau_{\textnormal{KL}} is more prominent (Table II). So our approximator of choice is Ïˆconfsubscriptğœ“conf\psi_{\textnormal{conf}} with Ï„KLsubscriptğœKL\tau_{\textnormal{KL}}.

Table IV shows experimental results of the different combinations of grouping criteria GSsubscriptğºğ‘†G_{S}. We remind that the goal of our approach is to group clients with different distributions in the same superclient, in order to obtain heterogeneous ones. To this end, our evaluation metrics are the balance ratio and covered classes (see Section IV-B3 of the main paper), as a way to reflect the heterogeneity of superclientâ€™s dataset.
The approximators classifierAll, classifierLast2 and classifierLast refer respectively to extracting the weights of all, the last two or only the last fully connected layer from our network of choice, LeNet-5. In practice, since we apply PCA on the network parameters (Figure 5), extracting all the classifierâ€™s weights does not introduce much additional computational burden. Moreover, classifierAll achieves the best performance among the three options. Therefore we choose to always extract all the weights.
Results are consistent across the dataset and show that the best combinations are GSa={Ïˆclf,Ï•greedy,Ï„câ€‹oâ€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹e}subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘ğ‘†subscriptğœ“clfsubscriptitalic-Ï•greedysubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘’G^{a}_{S}=\{\psi_{\textnormal{clf}},\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}},\tau_{cosine}\} and GSb={Ïˆconf,Ï•greedy,Ï„câ€‹oâ€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹e}subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘ğ‘†subscriptğœ“confsubscriptitalic-Ï•greedysubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘’G^{b}_{S}=\{\psi_{\textnormal{conf}},\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}},\tau_{cosine}\}. Experimental results on the performance of FedSeq given such grouping criteria show that on the average case GSc={Ïˆconf,Ï•greedy,Ï„Kâ€‹L}subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘ğ‘†subscriptğœ“confsubscriptitalic-Ï•greedysubscriptğœğ¾ğ¿G^{c}_{S}=\{\psi_{\textnormal{conf}},\phi_{\textnormal{greedy}},\tau_{KL}\} leads to best results (see Section IV-B3).
